description: The Network+ certification was introduced by CompTIA in 1999 and was designed to do for Network Technicians what the A+ certification did for Computer Technicians. Obtaining Network+ certification shows that the holder possess the same knowledge and skills of someone who has worked for nine months as a Network Technician. The Network+ exam covers topics ranging from theory (terminology, topology and design) to hardware (routers, switches and cabling) and provides users with a broad, vendor neutral perspective on the topics required to work in the field of Network Administration.
descriptionMD: The _Network+ certification_ was introduced by CompTIA in 1999 and was designed to do for Network Technicians what the A+ certification did for Computer Technicians. Obtaining Network+ certification shows that the holder possess the same knowledge and skills of someone who has worked for nine months as a Network Technician. The Network+ exam covers topics ranging from theory (terminology, topology and design) to hardware (routers, switches and cabling) and provides users with a broad, vendor neutral perspective on the topics required to work in the field of Network Administration.  __This course has been CAQC'd and qualifies for CEU credits. [Click here](https://itpro.tv/comptia-partnership) to get an exam voucher discount.__
name: Network+
subtitle: Vendor-neutral Networking

episodes.description: The Network+ certification was introduced by CompTIA in 1999. It was designed to do for Network Technicians what the A+ certification did for Computer Technicians. Obtaining the Network+ certification shows that the holder possess the same knowledge and skills of someone who has worked for nine months as a Network Technician. The Network+ exam covers topics ranging from theory (terminology, topology and design) to hardware (routers, switches and cabling) to provide the learner with a broad, vendor neutral perspective on the topics required to work in the field
episodes.title: Network+ Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel take you through some of the various network devices that you will most likely encounter as a network tech in the field. They explain in great detail network appliances like routers, switches, firewalls, and even intrusion detection/prevention systems.
episodes.title: Various Network Devices

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel continue on with familiarizing you with various network devices. Here they cover network appliances like content filters, load balancers, and VPN concentrators.
episodes.title: Various Network Devices Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel describe and demonstrate some of the networking services and applications that a Network+ certified tech will need to support. In great detail, they explain and even show you the "science" behind Virtual Private Networks (VPN) from learning what a VPN is, to the various types of VPNs and their associated encryption types and tunnels.
episodes.title: Networking Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue exploring different networking services and applications; specifically diving into remote authentication, authorization, and accounting servers (TACACS/RADIUS), Remote Access Servers (RAS), VoIP, and more.
episodes.title: Networking Services Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain how to install and configure some of the various networking services/applications that are found on a typical network. Topics covered in no small detail include DHCP and DNS; two of the major services found on most networks.
episodes.title: Networking Services/Applications

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie pick back up the task of explaining how to install and configure various networking services/applications. This time they are covering Proxy servers and their various applications. Also covered is Network Address Translation (NAT) and Port Forwarding.
episodes.title: Networking Services/Applications Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie examine the different network topologies and types covered in the Net+ exam. They cover all the bases starting with Mesh topologies and working all the way through Bus, Ring, Star, and Hybrid. Also covered are network types like Point-to-Point and Client/Server.
episodes.title: Common Network Topologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain the different network infrastructures and how they are implemented. Common implementations like WAN, MAN, and LAN are covered as well as some more specialized networks like Industrial Control Systems (ICS) and Medianets.
episodes.title: Network Infrastructures

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue exploring the different routing protocols as well as covering the myriad of routing metrics used to calculate route paths. Also, they show you how to increase the availability of a network by employing redundancy protocols like Virtual Routing Redundancy Protocol (VRRP) and Hot Standby Routing Protocol (HSRP)
episodes.title: Basic Routing Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel explain the basics of Unified Communication (UC) technologies like Voice over IP phone systems, video conferencing, and other real-time services. They also give you an overview of the UC servers, end devices, and gateways that facilitate the various UC services.
episodes.title: Communication Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore and contrast the technologies that support virtualization and cloud services. They go over the different virtualized network hardware like virtual routers, switches, and NICs as well as covering the topic of storage over a network. Cloud services like IaaS, SaaS, and PaaS are also discussed.
episodes.title: Cloud and Virtualization

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take you through all the considerations to take into account when designing and building a basic network. They explain some of the advantages as well as the disadvantages when it comes to both wired and wireless network, while also showing you some of the devices needed to implement either.
episodes.title: Building a Basic Network

episodes.description: In this episode Don begins the multipart series on IPv4 subnetting. He begins with a detailed discussion on what a subnet is, what it does and what we use it for. He continues with explaining the process of decimal to binary conversion and how to determine whether an IP address is part of the same network as another address.
episodes.title: IPv4 Subnetting

episodes.description: In this episode Don continues with a discussion on IPv4 subnetting with leveraging the use of subnets to create smaller or larger network to optimize network performance. He uses examples of splitting and combining networks to ensure enough IP address are available for network devices.
episodes.title: IPv4 Subnetting Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Don describes the characteristics of IP addressing. He begins with breaking down the IP address to binary conversion and how the subnet mask comes into play in determining which class the IP address belongs to. He wraps the show with a discussion on the main classes of IP addresses; both public and private classes.
episodes.title: IP Addressing

episodes.description: In this episode Don covers the characteristics of IPv6 addressing. He begins by comparing IPv6 to IPv4 address and how they differ. He discusses the various classes of IPv6 addresses such as the private, loopback, multicast and link-local addresses.
episodes.title: IPv6 Addressing

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue walking you through different types of monitoring and monitoring tools. They show you how to use monitors like Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) for collecting security logs from multiple points; and then show how to do some wireless monitoring for getting the most efficient wireless network setup. Also covered is environmental and power monitoring.
episodes.title: Monitoring Tools

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue walking you through different types of monitoring and monitoring tools. They show you how to use monitors like Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) for collecting security logs from multiple points; and then show how to do some wireless monitoring for getting the most efficient wireless network setup. Also covered is environmental and power monitoring.
episodes.title: Monitoring Tools Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain how to analyze the info and reports gathered by your monitoring and performance tools. They explain some of the basic concepts like baselines and bottlenecks and then get into more detailed concepts like interface monitoring output, graphs, and utilization charts.
episodes.title: Analyzing Metrics and Reports

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain how to implement certain resources to support and manage your network and/or system configurations. They describe the importance of having good backups and network documentation, the basics of Network Access Control systems, asset management, and network diagrams.
episodes.title: Support Config Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the importance of network segmentation. They explain the logic behind the need to segregate networks and give examples of the types of systems that might need segmenting like SCADA, test environments, and legacy systems.
episodes.title: Network Segmentation

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the importance and procedure for installing and applying various types of patches and updates. They talk about vulnerability patches, driver updates, and firmware updates. They also explain why you might need to downgrade an updated system and the difference between the two.
episodes.title: Patches and Updates

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain the functions of a network switch as well as its features and configuration. They show you how to create things like VLANs, set a default gateway and configure IP addresses. They also explain features like Power-over-Ethernet(PoE) and VLAN-Trunking-Protocol (VTP) and how they can benefit your network.
episodes.title: Configuring Switches

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue explaining switch configuration. They expound on switch management by discussing user authentication; both locally and server based (AAA). They also instruct you on how to connect to a managed switch via a console cable or through remote protocols like telnet.
episodes.title: Configuring Switches Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss implementing wireless infrastructure and the technologies that support it. They explain the different wireless devices like Access Points and the various mobile devices. Then they discuss topics like placement, antennae types, and wireless topologies.
episodes.title: Wireless Infrastructure

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie go over the basic concepts that pertain to risk management and disaster recovery. They explore the standards, policies, and procedures that will help ensure business continuity in the event of a worst-case scenario. Topics covered include disaster recovery, data breaches, end-user awareness and training, and risk mitigation through vulnerability testing and redundancy.
episodes.title: Risk Related Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the various techniques used when implementing network hardening. They cover security techniques such as antivirus/antimalware for the workstation and the network wire. They also demonstrate switch port security that helps in maintaining data and workstation integrity. Also discussed is the importance of using secure protocols like SSH, SSL, and IPsec.
episodes.title: Network Hardening Techniques

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue explaining the various techniques used when implementing network hardening. They cover the use of Access Control Lists (ACL) and web proxies to filter content, wireless security, and user authentication techniques like PAP, CHAP, and Kerberos. Hashing to maintain integrity is also covered.
episodes.title: Network Hardening Techniques Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain and contrast the various physical controls that can be implemented for security. They discuss physical security measures like Mantraps, video surveillance systems, biometrics, and electronic lock systems.
episodes.title: Physical Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie go over the basic concepts of digital forensics. They introduce you to the standard practices and procedures for handling an incident be it accidental or criminal. They cover concepts like eDiscovery, documentation, chain of custody, and data transport.
episodes.title: Basic Forensic Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the basics of installing and configuring a firewall. They explain the differences between the types of firewalls, whether they be software or hardware, the type of firewall service they can provide, as well as some practical use and implementation.
episodes.title: Basic Firewall Config

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain the how, when, and where of implementing Network Access Control (NAC) systems. They give an overview of NAC operations for granting and denying access to networks and network resources and then describe the different NAC models like Mandatory, Discretionary, Role and Rule based.
episodes.title: Access Control Models

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie walk you through the CompTIA network troubleshooting method. Step-by-step they explore and explain each process; from identifying the problem, to implementing a solution and documenting your findings.
episodes.title: Net+ Troubleshooting Theory

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss troubleshooting and resolving common wireless issues. They explain various issues like signal loss, interference, overlapping channels, and channel saturation.
episodes.title: Common Wireless Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie walk you through common issues with copper cable media. They discuss troubleshooting problems like electrical shorts and cuts, incorrect termination, and interference from other electrical devices.
episodes.title: Copper Cable Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss troubleshooting, and resolving common issue with fiber optic cables. They cover issues like signal attenuation, wavelength mismatches, and bend radius limitations.
episodes.title: Common Fiber Optics Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike walk you through many common security issues and what you can do to troubleshoot and resolve them. They discuss security problems like misconfigured firewalls, denial of service attacks, malicious users, and authentication issues.
episodes.title: Resolving Security Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain how to troubleshoot and resolve common WAN issues. They describe the different types of equipment involved with connecting WANs along with techniques for resolving problems with that equipment when they arise. Also discussed is router interface errors and misconfiguration issue as well as DNS and even satellite WAN issues.
episodes.title: Common WAN Issues

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Ronnie take a look at some of easily overlooked network issues that can cause networking performance issues.  They show and discuss not only issues that directly relate to the end user but also at the network service level and network infrastructure.
episodes.title: Common Network Issues

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike describe the layers of the OSI reference model. They walk you through each layer describing its purpose and how it is used when sending and receiving data over a computer network.
episodes.title: OSI Layers

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe many of the basic networking theories and concepts you might encounter as a network technician. Topics covered include data encapsulation, signal modulation/multiplexing, and data collision detection and avoidance.
episodes.title: Basic Network Theory

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Ronnie take a look a different scenarios that IT professionals must consider implementing policies and procedures. They show some of the different templates available and discuss why they are needed.
episodes.title: Policies and Procedures

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Ronnie take a look into some of the most common safety practices around high voltage, equipment installation, chemical spills and emergencies.  They also describe fire supression systems including Clean Agent.
episodes.title: Safety Practices

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Ronnie talk about equipment installation considerations including basic scability in design to practical installation matters like power, placement and monitoring systems to be considered. They show example from the ITProTV facilities.
episodes.title: Managing Equipment

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Ronnie discuss the needs and procedures of basic change management.  They talk about the importance of documentation and communication that should be part of every IT team when equipment changes, configuration changes and event changes can impact the network.
episodes.title: Change Management

topics.title: Industry standards, practices, and network theory

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel explore a few miscellaneous topics pertaining to wired and wireless technologies. Here they cover media converters like Single-Mode Fiber to Ethernet, Multimode Fiber to Ethernet, Fiber to Coax, and Single Mode to Multimode Fiber.
episodes.title: Additional Information

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel look at a few more miscellaneous topics; this time looking at IPv6 related content. Here they cover DHCP6, which is automatic addressing of nodes using the IPv6 networking protocol. They explain stateless, stateful, and manual configurations. They also cover IPv6 in a still largely IPv4 world and how the two can coexist with 6to4/4to6 tunneling and Teredo/Miredo.
episodes.title: Additional Information Part 2
